Something to keep in mind: to measure calories, measure the amount of heat put out by burning something after removing the water from it; after all, food basically undergoes a combustion reaction in your body (through a slightly more complicated pathway to make sure it's as energy-efficient as possible without literally burning your cells). So yeah, not surprising that starch-based and protein-based powders burn well.

You can avoid some of the awkwardness and moisture induction of blowing through the tube by attaching a sphygmomanometer (or similar type), bulb to it's end and running the tube up the side of the torch.  Dropping a balled fist onto the bulb will produce a measurably similar puff of air through the tube and straight into the corona of the flame.  You'll find the results to be superior to the rather 'hit-or-miss' method.  Remember, it's all fun and games until you start taking notes.  Then, it's science.
